The technical aspect of golf can be overwhelming, especially when you're starting out! It's great that you're watching YouTube videos, but sometimes it's hard to translate online instruction into real-life results.

Here's a suggestion: consider recording yourself swinging. You can use a smartphone or ask a friend to record you from different angles (face-on, down-the-line, etc.). This will help you identify areas for improvement and track your progress over time.

Additionally, focus on one aspect of your swing at a time. Instead of trying to fix everything at once, work on one thing, like your grip, stance, or backswing. Make small adjustments and practice regularly to build muscle memory.

Another tip is to slow down your swing. Many beginners try to swing too fast, which can lead to poor technique and inconsistent results. Focus on making a smooth, controlled swing, even if it means sacrificing some distance.

Lastly, don't be afraid to take lessons from a golf instructor. They can provide personalized feedback, correct any bad habits, and help you develop a consistent swing. Group lessons or beginner classes are also a great way to learn from others and get feedback from an instructor.

Remember, the key is to be patient and persistent. Don't get discouraged if you don't see immediate results. With consistent practice and a willingness to learn, you'll start to see improvement over time.

What do you think is the most challenging part of your swing? Is it the backswing, downswing, or impact?
